body:
to further add to my conundrum, i decided to remove owncloud and start a clean install.
i even tried installing the latest debian package, yet the problem remains.

i think i have narrowed the problem to an issue with libapache2-mod-php5 and libapache2-mod-php5filter, as seen here:

http://apache-http-server.18135.n6.nabble.com/issue-with-http-methods-delete-put-not-being-accepted-returning-405-method-not-allowed-td4999776.html#a4999806

unfortunately, when i disable the php5filter mod and only enable php5 mod, owncloud (or rather apache) serves up the owncloud/index.php file to be opened as a file rather than executing the php code.

with php5filter mod enabled, i can login through the web without any problem (php is properly executed), and i can even login with the oc android app (i see a 200 response in the apache logs). however, that seems to be the extent of what i can do. when i try to upload a file or create a directory through the oc android app, i get the familiar 405 error. i have the dav module also enabled, even though oc is supposed to have its own webdav engine.

xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx - username[20/nov/2012:18:15:02 +0000] "get /status.php http/1.1" 200 583 "-" "android-owncloud"
xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx - - [20/nov/2012:18:15:02 +0000] "propfind /remote.php/webdav/ http/1.1" 405 495 "-" "android-owncloud"
xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx - - [20/nov/2012:18:29:07 +0000] "put /remote.php/webdav/testfile.txt http/1.1" 405 524 "-" "android-owncloud"
xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx - - [20/nov/2012:18:29:29 +0000] "mkcol /remote.php/webdav/test/ http/1.1" 405 626 "-" "android-owncloud"


to sum up, it seems that get works fine, yet commands like propfind, put, mkcol and others are being blocked.
again, i had my oc instance working flawlessly before updating to 4.5.2., but it seems to me the issue could be related to php/apache2 and squeeze.

any ideas would be appreciated as i'm going nuts trying to fix this.

thanks

digging deeper into the rabbit hole, i think the problem is that debian squeeze's latest update broke php compatibility with owncloud.

can someone else running squeeze confirm they're having the same issues please? and is there any simple fix before i go messing around and likely break things even further?

thanks

from http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=687307

"--cut here--
php5 (5.4.4-5) unstable; urgency=low

 please be aware that the mime-support package has dropped non-standard
 definitions for php that might affect any systems using php 5 running
 as cgi or fastcgi.  the following definitions were dropped:

  application/x-httpd-php                        phtml pht php
  application/x-httpd-php-source                 phps
  application/x-httpd-php3                       php3
  application/x-httpd-php3-preprocessed          php3p
  application/x-httpd-php4                       php4
  application/x-httpd-php5                       php5

 the php5-cgi package mitigates any known issues by creating a (dummy)
 apache2 module php5_cgi with a configuration containing handlers for
 all previously defined extensions.  ****even though we believe that this
 configuration should keep your php scripts interpreted, it might be a
 good idea to check your apache2 site-wide configuration as well as
 any specific php configuration for websites running on your system.****

 as far as we know definitions from the mime-support packages are not
 used in any other webserver included in debian, but it might affect
 any application which relies on system mime types to interpret php
 files.
--cut here--

i am currently thinking how to accomodate all types of users (cgi and
fastcgi), but i haven't come to any conclusion yet. if you have an
idea, how to not break the configuration for neither cgi nor fastcgi
users, feel free to share.

ok, solved.
in case anyone else has this problem, the issue is that squeeze's latest update changes some php configs as suspected.
the solution, for me, was to remove libapache2-mod-php5filter and install libapache2-mod-php5 from dotdeb since it's no longer available in the debian packages (see http://www.debian-tutorials.com/how-to-install-and-use-php5-fpm-with-apache2-on-debian).

after doing all that, my installation is working again.

i just wish i hadn't spent 2 days finding and correcting this silly bug/"feature"....
